questions.question: Which piece moves in an L-shape?
questions.explaination: The Knight moves in an L-shape: two squares in one direction, then one perpendicular.

questions.question: Which piece starts on the corners?
questions.explaination: Rooks start in the corners of the chessboard and move horizontally or vertically.

questions.question: Which piece moves diagonally?
questions.explaination: Bishops move diagonally across the board, with no limit on distance per move.

questions.question: How many squares does a King move?
questions.explaination: The King moves one square in any direction: forward, backward, sideways, or diagonally.

questions.question: Which piece can jump over others?
questions.explaination: The Knight is the only piece that can jump over other pieces on the board.

questions.question: Which is the most powerful piece?
questions.explaination: The Queen is the most powerful piece, moving vertically, horizontally, and diagonally.

questions.question: Which piece only moves forward?
questions.explaination: Pawns move forward one square but capture diagonally, and can move two squares on first move.

questions.question: What is it called when the King cannot escape?
questions.explaination: Checkmate occurs when the King is in check and cannot escape or block the threat.

questions.question: What is castling?
questions.explaination: Castling is a special move involving the King and Rook, enhancing the King's safety.

questions.question: How many pawns does each player start with?
questions.explaination: Each player starts with 8 pawns, which are positioned in the second row.
